subsection.heading: 1.1 Introduction
subsection.p: Consider the following Spanish sentence: 1,2

(1)
Juana quiere verlo.
Juana want-pres-3sg see+it
‘Juana wants (to) see it.’
Here the matrix verb querer ‘want’ is followed by an infinitival complement containing a direct object expressed by the clitic lo. Spanish has an alternative for (1), which is presented in (2):

(2)
Juana lo
quiere. ver.
Juana it want-pres-3sg see
‘Juana wants (to) see it.’

The sentences in (1) and (2) have the same interpretation, but in (2) the clitic appears attached to the matrix verb. 3 Though this is not a logical necessity, many linguists assume that (1) and (2) are derivationally related, in the sense that both involve the same D-structure. We will follow this assumption here (but see section 3.2). In the case of the in situ variant (1) the clitic stays in the complement, but in the clitic climbing variant (2) the clitic moves or ‘climbs’ out of the latter and attaches to a higher host. Clitic climbing (Cl Cl) is known to occur in various languages, such as Spanish, Italian, and Portuguese, Dutch and German, Serbo-Croatian, and the West African Kru languages. 4 Cl Cl constructions are in some sense anomalous: their anomalous nature consists in the fact that the clitics appear in the matrix domain rather than in the complement domain in which they are generated, without there being an obvious trigger that causes them to move to the former. As such, theorizing about these constructions involves an attempt at a deeper and more subtle understanding of the means Universal Grammar has available for the expression of clausal complement relations.

In the discussion that follows we will restrict ourselves to Cl Cl in Romance, about which there exists a considerable amount of literature. 5 In section 1.2 we will present an overview of the main properties of the construction, which we summarize in subsection 1.2.6. This overview will be followed – in section 1.3 – by a sketch of the central issue involved in the research on the Cl Cl construction.

subsection.heading: 1.2 Properties of the Cl Cl construction
1.2.1 Cl Cl verbs
subsection.p: Cl Cl occurs with a restricted set of matrix verbs and as such constitutes an exception, rather than a rule. The verbs that allow it are mainly modal, aspectual, and movement verbs. 6 Thus, for instance, the modal verb querer in the examples in (1) and (2) contrasts with the verb odiar in (3), which cannot act as a host for Cl Cl:

(3)
a. Juana odia verlo.
Juana hate-pres-3sg see+it
‘Juan hates (to) see it.’
b. *Juana lo odia ver.
Both querer and odiar are subject control verbs, selecting a CP (S′) complement. Cl Cl also occurs with raising verbs, which select IP (S) complements. An example is soler in (4):

(4)
a. Juana suele leerlo
por la mañana.
Juana tend-pres-3sg read+it for the morning
‘Juana tends to read it in the morning.’
b. Juana lo suele leer por la mañana.
A raising verb that doesn't allow for Cl Cl is the verb parecer, as in (5): 7

(5)
a. Juana parece saberlo.
Juana seem-pres-3sg know+it
‘Juana seems (to) know it.’
b. *Juana lo parece saber.

subsection.heading: 1.2.2 Optionality and clustering
subsection.p: As one can deduce from the examples in (1), (2), and (4), Cl Cl is optional. In other words, there is always a choice between an in situ variant and a Cl Cl variant. 8 However, if the complement contains more than one clitic, as in (6) – where the clitics are me and lo – and the climbing option is chosen, it must involve all the clitics, as in (7a). Thus, neither (7b), with me in situ and lo attached to quiere, nor (7c), with these options reversed, is grammatical: 9

(6)
Juana no quiere entregármelo.
Juana not want-pres-3sg give+me+it
‘Juana doesn't want to give it to me.’

(7)
a. Juana no me lo quiere entregar.
b. *Juana no me quiere entregarlo.
c. *Juana no lo quiere entregarme.

subsection.heading: 1.2.3 Structural relation between host and clitic
subsection.p: A further property of Cl Cl is that it is strongly restricted by structural conditions: the only configuration in which it can apply is the one in (8), where V1 is the semantic head of CP/IP and the clitic is contained in the same minimal CP/IP as V1:
(8) [V′ V2 [CP/IP V1 Cl]]

Given this configuration, V1 will normally act as the host in the in situ variant and V2 as the host after Cl Cl. The situation is somewhat more complex when auxiliaries are involved, but here we abstract from those.

As can be deduced from (8), Cl Cl is impossible when the clitic originates in a clause that is not governed by the verbal host, i.e., that is not a complement of this host. 10 As such, Cl Cl respects the general condition which prohibits extraction from subjects and adjuncts, i.e., the Condition on Extraction Domains of Huang (1982a), which shows that it is a normal syntactic process. The pairs of examples in (9) and (10) are meant as an illustration of this point. In both cases the main verb is a Cl Cl verb. The in situ version in (9a) involves a clitic contained in a subject (leerlo bien). (9b) is its Cl Cl variant, which is ungrammatical. In (10a) a comprarlo is an adjunct phrase; the Cl Cl counterpart (10b) is again ungrammatical:

(9)
a. [Leerlo
bien] debe requerir mucha paciencia.
read+it well must-pres-3sg require much patience
‘To read it well must require much patience.’
b. *[Leer bien] lo debe requerir mucha paciencia.

(10)
a. A qué tienda vas [a comprarlo]?
To which shop go-pres-2sg to buy+it
‘To which shop do you go in order to buy it?’
b. *A qué tienda lo vas [a comprar]?

Another consequence of the fact that the clitic must originate in the clause that is governed by the host is that Cl Cl is locally bounded. Thus, for instance, in (11) where the clause the clitic lo belongs to is governed by (non-Cl Cl) odiar, but not by the Cl Cl verb suele, climbing of lo onto this latter verb is excluded (11b):

(11)
a. Juana suele [odiar [hacerlo]].
Juana tend-pres-3sg hate do+it
‘Juana tends (to) hate (to) do it.’
b. *Juana lo suele odiar hacer.
There is one apparent exception to this local boundedness: intervening verbs that themselves belong to the Cl Cl class do not prevent climbing onto a higher host. We exemplify this in (12):

(12)
a. Juana quisiera poder hacerlo.
Juana want-cond-past-3sg can do+it
‘Juana would want to be able to do it.’
b. Juana lo quisiera poder hacer.

Here the intervening head poder, a Cl Cl verb, does not prevent climbing of the clitic lo onto the higher verb quisiera. We may, however, assume that Cl Cl proceeds recursively, that is, that the in situ variant of (12b) is in fact (13):
(13) Juana quisiera poderlo hacer

If, on the other hand, we assume that the clitic climbs directly onto the host quisiera we must allow for the semantic head of IP/CP in (8) not only being the in situ host of the clitic, but any potential host.

subsection.heading: 1.2.4 Two further restrictions
subsection.p: There are two cases in which, even if the structural conditions discussed in the preceding subsection are met and the matrix verb is a Cl Cl verb, Cl Cl is impossible. The first involves finite complements. Such complements, of which que lo ves in (14a) is an example, never allow Cl Cl (cf. 14b):

(14)
a. Juana quiere que lo
ves.
Juana want-pres-3sg that it see-pres-2sg
‘Juana wants you to see it.’
b. *Juana lo quiere que ves.

(15)
a. Juana quiere no verlo.
‘Juana wants not (to) see it.’
b. *Juana lo quiere no ver.
The second case is that in which the complement contains a negation particle. As illustrated in (15), Cl Cl is blocked by the presence of such a particle: 11

subsection.heading: 1.2.5 Movement of V and complement
subsection.p: In the examples we have presented so far the the complement is right-adjacent to the matrix verb. At least for Italian, this adjacency is not a necessary requirement, however. In the first place, this language permits VP adverbs to occur between the two constituents, and in the second place, it permits the complement to appear in a left-peripheral position. Below we consider in turn each of these two cases, which, as we will show, occur as the result of movement.

The example in (16), from Cinque (2004), illustrates that the intervention of a VP adverb like subito between the matrix verb and the complement is compatible both with clitics in situ and with climbed clitics:

(16)
a. Verrò subito a scriverlo.
Come-fut-1sg at-once to write+it
‘I’ll come at once to write it.’
b.
Lo verrò subito a scrivere.

VP adverbs occur to the left of the VP and serve as a standard diagnostic for verb movement to I, which is a general process in the Romance Cl Cl languages. Example (16b) shows that V-to-I movement is not blocked by Cl Cl in Italian. 12
In the examples in (17) the complement occurs in the left periphery of the matrix clause:

(17)
a. [Leggerlo
a tutti] non potevo.
read+it to all not can-past-1sg
‘Read it to everybody, I couldn't.’
b. [Leggere a tutti] non lo potevo.

The complement in these cases functions as a topic. Left-peripheral topics are assumed to be preposed by Topicalization. From the grammaticality of the example in (17b) we can conclude that Topicalization of the complement is compatible with Cl Cl. 13

The above shows that both (Italian) matrix verbs and their complement can be moved from their base position in Cl Cl constructions. However, there is at least one case in which movement of the complement is incompatible with Cl Cl. This is the one involving clausal pied-piping (chapter 50) in Italian, discussed in Rizzi (1978). 14 Consider (18a), which represents the relevant aspects of the D-structure of a noun phrase containing a non-restrictive relative clause (the part between the outer square brackets). As the verb posso, or rather potere, ‘to be able’, is a Cl Cl verb, one expects the clitic ti to be able to climb out of its complement (indicated by the inner square brackets), with as a result the structure in (18b):

(18)
a. Il Direttore [, per il momento, proprio non posso [presentarti
al quale]].
the Director for the moment really not can-pres-1sg introduce+you to whom
b. Il Direttore [, per il momento, proprio non ti
posso [presentare al quale]].

To derive the complete S-structure, the relative constituent al quale must be preposed by wh-movement to the beginning of the relative clause. Italian can pied-pipe an infinitival clause in this kind of relative; that is, al quale when being preposed may take with it the whole complement of posso that contains it. For the in situ variant (18a) this gives the result in (19):

(19)
Il Direttore, presentarti al quale, per il momento, proprio non posso.
the director, introduce+you to whom, for the moment, really not can-pres-1sg
‘The Director, to introduce you to whom, for the time being I really cannot.’
The relevant case, however, is the Cl Cl variant (20): preposing the complement here apparently destroys the relation between the Cl Cl host and its complement and leads to an ungrammatical result:
(20) *Il Direttore, presentare al quale, per il momento, propio non ti posso.
This concludes our discussion of the main properties of Cl Cl, which we summarize in subsection 1.2.6.

subsection.heading: 1.2.6 Summary
subsection.p: As shown in subsections 1.2.1–1.2.5, Cl Cl has the following characteristics:

li.p: Cl Cl only applies with a small class of matrix verbs.
Cl Cl is optional, but doesn't allow for split clitics.
Cl Cl may only apply out of non-finite complements governed by a Cl Cl verb.
Cl Cl is incompatible with the presence of a negative particle in the complement.
Cl Cl hosts may be separated from their complement by V-to-I movement (at least in Italian).
Cl Cl constructions show restrictions with respect to fronting of the complement.

subsection.p: It is obvious that the theory of grammar must aim at explaining these distinct properties. It is also obvious that the core of this explanation will involve the special nature of Cl Cl verbs. In the following section we will present a first approximation to the line of research required to unveil their exceptional character.

subsection.heading: 1.3 Clitic Placement and the Clause Mate Condition
subsection.p: The fundamental question about Cl Cl verbs is what exactly allows these verbs to ‘attract’ clitics from their complement clause, thereby relaxing the usual locality conditions on clitic attachment. This immediately raises an underlying question, which is: what exactly are these conditions? Though there are some specific proposals on this point, we will not discuss these as yet. What we will do here is indicate the direction in which these must be sought.

There is some discussion in the literature as to whether the morphological units formed by clitics and verbs are base-generated or produced derivationally. As virtually all the work on Cl Cl assumes the latter option, we will do the same here. 15 Under this assumption, clitics are generated in XP positions in the base and are attached to the verb by means of a rule of Clitic Placement (Cl Pl). 16 Thus, Cl Pl transforms, for instance, the D-structure in (21a) into the structure in (21b):

(21)
a. Juana ve [DP lo].
Juana see-pres-3sg it
‘Juana sees it.’
b. Juana lo+ve t.

Even in simplex clauses, however, the host of a clitic is not always the verb responsible for its semantic role. We refer to clauses containing, in addition to the main verb, one or more auxiliaries. 17 Auxiliaries in Romance are perfective, passive, or aspectual. Perfective and passive auxiliaries select VPs headed by past participles and aspectual auxiliaries VPs headed by gerunds. 18 In the case of past participles, clitics always attach to the auxiliary. We exemplify this for a perfective auxiliary (22), a passive auxiliary (23), and a combination of both (24):

(22)
a. *Juana ha vistolo.
Juana have-pres-3sg seen+it
‘Juana has seen it.’
b. Juana lo ha visto.

(23)
a. *El libro fue entregádome.
The book be-pres-3sg given+me
‘The book was given to me.’
b. El libro me fue entregado.

(24)
a. *El libro ha sido entregádome.
The book have-pres-3g been given+me
‘The book has been given to me.’
b. El libro me ha sido entregado.
In the case of gerunds, on the other hand, there are two options: the clitic appears either on the gerund or on the auxiliary:

(25)
a. Juana estaba cantándolo.
Juana was-past-3sg singing+it
‘Juana was singing it.’
b. Juana lo estaba cantando.

Thus, in clauses with auxiliaries, Cl Pl obviously must or can target the (highest) auxiliary, instead of the main verb. Notice that this instance of Cl Pl is remarkably similar to Cl Cl: we can say that the clitic ‘climbs’ out of the VP in order to attach to the auxiliary. In the same vein, but from a different perspective, it is generally assumed that Cl Cl is in fact a case of Cl Pl, comparable to Cl Pl with auxiliaries in the sense that in both cases the host is higher than the verb the clitic ‘belongs’ to. 19

Apart from the obligatoriness of ‘climbing’ in cases such as those in (22–24), there is one other crucial difference between regular Cl Cl verbs and auxiliaries: while the former are exceptions among the class of verbs selecting clausal complements, the latter all require or allow climbing. We may deduce from this that Auxiliary Cl Cl (Cl Pl targeting auxiliaries) is unconstrained. Apparently, thus, the constraint that prevents Cl Cl with normal raising or control verbs must be sought in the difference between their type of complement and the complement type of auxiliaries. Consider in this respect the relevant aspects of an auxiliary and a raising construction in, respectively, (26a) and (26b):

(26)
a. V [VP V]
b. V [IP subject [I′ I [VP V]]]

The raising construction (26b) differs from the auxiliary construction (26a) in that, in addition to the VP, it contains an IP boundary, a subject, an I′ projection, and an I-head. It follows that the constraint under consideration must be due to the presence of at least one of these elements. Until section 6 we will not be concerned with a specific proposal. We only establish that for some reason clitics normally cannot cross sentential boundaries (as opposed to VP boundaries). This is sometimes referred to as the Clause Mate Condition, which here is meant to indicate that a clitic and its trace must occur in the same clause. 20 We will also employ this term, but it must be kept in mind that it is merely descriptive. As the structure of control complements (27) forms an extension of that involving raising complements, we can simply assume that the constraining factor that holds for the latter is present here as well. Of course the term ‘Clause Mate Condition’ is also applicable in this case:
(27)V [CP [IP [VP V cl]]]

One possible hypothesis about Cl Cl verbs might be that they are ‘stronger’ than other verbs, in the sense that they have some kind of ‘magnetic force’ by which they so strongly attract clitics that the constraining factor can simply be ignored. However, there exists clear evidence that matters are more complex. This evidence, which consists of a set of data involving exceptional (applications of) rules in the same circumstances as those holding for Cl Cl, will be discussed in the next section.

subsection.heading: 2.1 Introduction
subsection.p: In this section we will show that certain locality restrictions on both DP-movement (section 2.2) and wh-movement (section 2.3) are relaxed in the case of infinitival complements of Cl Cl verbs. In section 2.4 we will, furthermore, consider an exceptional property of perfect participles of a subset of Cl Cl verbs in Italian, which consists in the fact that the choice of their auxiliary can be determined by the complement verb. For each of the phenomena we discuss we will consider how far it correlates with the Cl Cl variant and/or the in situ variant. In section 2.5 we present a summary.

subsection.heading: 2.2 Long DP-Movement
subsection.p: Normally DP-Movement involves movement from a position governed by a verb to the subject position of the clause of which the verb is the semantic head. In control Cl Cl constructions, however, a DP governed by the complement verb may move to the subject position of the matrix clause, across the embedded PRO subject. This can only happen, of course, if the matrix subject position – which normally contains the controller – is empty. The situation in which this is so is in passives. Most Cl Cl verbs reject passivization, for independent reasons. However, Italian (control) cominciare ‘begin’ and continuare ‘continue’ form an exception and the phenomenon of Long DP-Movement can be demonstrated for their passive forms, as in the example in (28a), from Burzio (1986). We add the relevant details of the analysis in (28b):

(28)
a. Il palazzo fu cominciato a costruire sotto Carlo V.
the palace be-past-3sg begun to build under Charles V
‘They began to build the palace under Charles V.’
b. Il palazzoi fu cominciato [CP a PRO costruire ti].

Apart from the standard passive, Romance has a construction known as ‘Reflexive Passive’ or ‘Middle’ which crucially involves the presence of the reflexive clitic se (Spanish, Portuguese), si (Italian), instead of passive morphology. 21 A simplex case is that in (29):

(29)
Las casasi
se vendieron ti.
the houses SE sell-pres-3pl
‘The houses were sold.’
‘They sold the houses.’
The Reflexive Passive occurs freely with control Cl Cl verbs and, as shown in the following example from Aissen and Perlmutter (1976), involves Long DP-Movement: 22

(30)
a. Estas secciones de la ciudad se quieren eliminar sin que nadie lo sepa.
these sections of the city SE want-pres-3pl eliminate without that no one it
knows
‘They want to eliminate these sections of the city without anyone knowing it.’
b. Estas secciones de la ciudadi se quieren [CP PRO eliminar ti] . . .

There is a strong correlation between Long DP-Movement and Cl Cl: sentences with Long DP-Movement and complement clitics are grammatical when the latter climb, but not when they remain in situ: see (31), an example from Zubizarreta (1980). In this sense Long DP-Movement can be classified as a true corollary of Cl Cl: 23

(31)
a. *Estas casas se quieren venderle
a alto precio.
these houses SE want-pres-3pl sell+him for high price
‘They want to sell him these houses for a high price.’
b. Estas casas se le quieren vender a alto precio.

subsection.heading: 2.3 Long Null Operator Movement
subsection.p: Long wh-movement is quite general in Romance, and hence it cannot tell us anything specific about Cl Cl constructions. There is, however, one process that is standardly assumed to be of the wh-type, which in the languages under consideration appears to obey the Clause Mate Condition. We refer to the process known as Null Operator Movement. 24 It applies in the infinitival complement of certain adjectives (tough/hard, easy, impossible) and, in Italian, in infinitival relatives. As we will see, the Clause Mate Condition on Null Operator Movement can be violated in the case of Cl Cl verbs.

(32a) contains an example of simplex complement governed by the adjective difícil ‘hard/tough’. (32b) gives the relevant aspects of its S-structure, which has been obtained by moving an empty element (the null operator) from the object position to Comp, where it is in the correct position to be interpreted as coreferent with the matrix subject:

(32)
a. Estas radios serán difíciles de componer.
these radios be-fut-3pl hard-pl to fix
‘These radios will be hard to fix.’
b. Estas radiosi serán difíciles [OPi de PRO componer ti]
In (33) we present an analogous Italian pair involving an infinitival relative, where the coreference is with the antecedent:

(33)
a. È una persona da ammirare.
be-pres-1sg a person to admire
‘He is someone to admire.’
b. È una personai [OPi da PRO ammirare ti].

In the ungrammatical examples in (34) the clauses containing the base position of the empty operator are governed not by the adjective or antecedent, but by, respectively, the verbs insistir and rimpiangere. Obviously, in such cases the operator cannot reach the higher Comp position in which it must be linked to the adjective (34a) or antecedent (34b). These examples show that Null Operator Movement is subject to the Clause Mate Condition:

(34)
a. *Tales cosas son difíciles de insistir en hacer.
such things be-pres-3sg hard-pl to insist on do
‘Such things are hard to insist on doing.’
b. *È una persona da rimpiangere di aver ammirato Italian
be-pres-3sg a person to regret to have admired
‘He is a person to regret to have admired.’

Consider now the sentences in (35), which structurally have the same properties as those in (34), but differ from them by the fact that the verb governing the complement with the empty object is a Cl Cl verb (dejar, continuare). Their grammaticality shows that movement of the wh-phrase to the front of the clause governed by the adjective or antecedent – i.e., Long Null Operator Movement – is available here. The Clause Mate Condition can apparently be violated in this case:

(35)
a. Estas galletas son casi imposibles de dejar de comer.
These cookies be-pres-3pl almost impossible-pl to stop to eat
‘These cookies are almost impossible to stop eating.’
b. È un argomento da continuare a studiare. Italian
be-pres-3sg an argument to continue to study
‘It is an argument to continue to study.’
The pair of examples in (36) indicates that Long Null Operator Movement and Cl Cl must go together: 25

(36)
a. *Cerco una cartolina da potere spedirgli. Italian
look for-pres-1sg a postcard to can send+him
b. Cerco una cartolina da potergli
spedire
look for-pres-1sg a postcard to can+him send
‘I'm looking for a postcard I can send him.’

subsection.heading: 2.4 Avere → Essere Shift
subsection.p: Unlike Spanish and Portuguese, Italian has two perfective auxiliaries. The first, avere ‘have’, occurs with unergative and transitive participles and the second, essere ‘be’, with unaccusative participles. A specific property of Italian Cl Cl constructions is that when the Cl Cl verb is a participle that normally requires avere, it can appear with essere if the complement verb is an essere verb. 26 Consider the examples in (37). In (37a) the participle of the Cl Cl verb volere ‘want’ combines with its normal auxiliary avere. As the complement verb tornare ‘return’ is an unaccusative verb, however, the auxiliary may also take the form è (from essere), as in (37b):

(37)
a. Mario ha voluto tornare a casa.
Mario have-pres-3sg wanted return to house
‘Mario has wanted to come back home.’
b. Mario è voluto tornare a casa.

Notice that the shift of auxiliary only involves avere-type participles. Cl Cl participles that occur with essere continue to require this auxiliary when the complement verb is an avere verb, as is fare in the following example: 27

(38)
a. Sono stato per fare una sciocchezza.
be-pres-1sg been for to do a foolish thing
‘I've been on the point of doing something foolish.’
b. *Ho stato per fare una sciocchezza.
have-pres-1sg been for do a foolish thing

As illustrated by the example in (37) above, the Avere → Essere Shift is optional. Rather than being a true corollary of Cl Cl it appears to be a condition for it. 28 That is, Cl Cl requires the shift (in the relevant context) (39a, b, c), but the latter may also apply with clitics in situ (39d):

(39)
a. Mario avrebbe proprio voluto andarci.
Mario have-cond-3sg really wanted go there
‘Mario would have really wanted to go there.’
b. *Mario ci avrebbe proprio voluto andare.
c. Mario ci
sarebbe proprio voluto andare.
Mario there be-cond-3sg really wanted go
d. Mario sarebbe proprio voluto andarci.

subsection.heading: 2.5 Summary
subsection.p: The properties of Cl Cl verbs discussed in this section are the following: 29

li.p: Cl Cl verbs permit Long DP-Movement over a PRO subject.
Cl Cl verbs allow for Long Null Operator Movement out of their complements.
Cl Cl participles can undergo Avere → Essere Shift (in Italian).

subsection.p: In (40) we summarize how the processes under consideration correlate with Cl Cl:

(40)
Cl Cl Cl in situ
Long DP-Movement Yes No
Long Null Operator Movement Yes No
Avere → Essere Shift Yes Yes
No Avere → Essere Shift No Yes

As we stated earlier, the fact that these phenomena typically occur with Cl Cl verbs indicates that Cl Cl cannot be studied separately from them. We could say that Cl Cl is simply the most salient epiphenomenon demonstrating the special character of the verbs that allow for it. 30 In the next sections we will consider distinct hypotheses that ultimately strive at unveiling this special character.

subsection.heading: 3.1 Introduction
subsection.p: The proposal about Cl Cl verbs that circumvents the Clause Mate Condition in the most radical way is the Dual Subcategorization Hypothesis. According to this hypothesis, the verbs are listed in the lexicon as optionally selecting either a CP/IP complement or a VP complement headed by an infinitival. 31 This entails that, contrary to what we have been assuming so far, they would appear in two different D-structures, (41a/b) or (41c):

(41)
Dual Subcategorization Hypothesis:
a. V [IP] or: c. V [VP]
b. V [CP]

The IP/CP option implies a structure identical to that of standard raising/control verbs, for which the Clause Mate Condition prevents the application of Cl Cl, so that this option is only compatible with the in situ variant. Likewise, Long DP and Long Null Operator Movement do not occur under this option, nor does Avere → Essere Shift.
In the case of the VP option, the relevant aspects of the D-structure of, e.g., Juana lo quiere ver will be as in (42):
(42) [CP [IP Juana I quiere [VP ver lo]]]

subsection.heading: 3.2 Apparent advantages of the Dual Subcategorization Hypothesis
subsection.p: Within the VP option, Cl Cl verbs actually have the same status as auxiliaries, so that the Clause Mate Condition is irrelevant and clitics can freely climb. What we have been calling Long Movement reduces to normal movement, targeting the only subject or Comp position that is available. The ‘complement’ verb is the main verb of the clause, so that it doesn't come as a surprise that when in Italian this verb is of the essere class it determines the choice of the auxiliary (but notice that we expect the same thing to happen for avere verbs, contrary to fact).
Under the VP option, Cl Cl is assumed to be obligatory, just like Cl Cl with perfective and passive auxiliaries. This means that the issue of clitic splitting does not arise.

Implicit in this approach is that infinitivals – like participials and gerunds – do not necessarily require a clausal projection, contrary to what happens with finite verbs. With the latter the VP option is unavailable and Cl Cl will be subject to the Clause Mate Condition.

The fact that Cl Cl is incompatible with the presence of a negative particle in the complement follows from the sentential status of this particle: it occurs in a clausal position (i.e., higher than VP) and such a position is absent by definition in VP complements.

In section 1.2.5 we saw that (Italian) Cl Cl verbs could be separated from their complement by V-to-I movement: as this is the normal situation for auxiliaries, this is what we expect. 32 The Italian example in (43), which is analogous to example (20), with which we illustrated that Cl Cl constructions show restrictions with respect to fronting of the complement, is intended to show that such restrictions also hold for standard VP complements. This entails that the hypothesis under consideration needs no independent explanation for the ungrammaticality of the Cl Cl case:

(43)
*Il Direttore, presentato mi figlio al quale, non ho mai.
the director, introduced my son to whom, not have-pres-1sg never

We see, thus, that the Dual Subcategorization Hypothesis, which is attractive in its simplicity, accounts for most of the facts involving the Cl Cl construction. There are, however, a considerable number of facts that seem to indicate that it is on the wrong track. We discuss those in a separate subsection.

subsection.heading: 3.3 Problems for the Dual Subcategorization Hypothesis
3.3.1 Cl Cl verbs and auxiliaries
subsection.p: Under the VP option of the Dual Subcategorization Hypothesis, Cl Cl verbs are auxiliaries. As we have already mentioned above, this accounts well for the Italian Avere → Essere Shift, but not for the fact that essere Cl Cl participles continue to take this auxiliary when the complement verb is of the avere type (as in (38) above). Moreover, the fact that the Avere → Essere Shift doesn't necessarily imply Cl Cl remains to be explained.

Another unexpected property of Cl Cl verbs as auxiliaries is that in Italian the latter sometimes can be passivized (and then occur with Long DP-Movement, cf. (28)). Passivization, of course, is a property of main verbs and not of auxiliaries.

A third difference between Cl Cl verbs and auxiliaries, mentioned in Goodall (1987b), also concerns Italian. In this language auxiliaries undergo a preposing rule known as Aux-to-C, as in (44a, b), but this doesn't hold true for Cl Cl verbs (44c):

(44)
a. Essendo state le mele mangiate . . .
being been the apples eaten
‘The apples having been eaten . . .’
b. Essendosi le mele mangiate . . .
being+SI the apples eaten
‘The apples having been eaten . . .’
c. *Essendosi potute le mele mangiate . . .
being+SI can.part the apples eaten
‘The apples having been able to be eaten . . .’

subsection.heading: 3.3.2 The structure of Cl Cl complements
subsection.p: Another serious problem for the Dual Subcategorization Hypothesis involves the fact that there are clear indications that Cl Cl complements have more structure than VPs. In the first place, as observed in Rooryck (1994a), the complement verb appears to the left of VP adverbs, which under standard assumptions indicates that it undergoes V-to-I movement, so that I must be present. We reproduce the Italian example Rooryck uses to illustrate this:

(45)
Piero ti verrà a (*spesso) parlare (spesso) di parapsicologia.
Piero you come-fut-3sg to (often) speak (often) of parapsychology
‘Piero will come to speak to you often about parapsychology.’

Further indication for more structure is presented by the so-called infinitival particles. 33 A number of Cl Cl verbs appear together with particles. Some Spanish examples are empezar a ‘start to’, tener que ‘must’ (lit.: ‘have that’), acabar de ‘just finish to’ (lit.: ‘finish of’), and estar por ‘be about to’ (lit.: ‘be for’). The particles are typically linked to the presence of an infinitival complement: they are absent with other uses of the same verbs, as illustrated for empezar a in (46):

(46)
a. Juana empieza a cantarlo.
Juana start-pres-3sg to sing+it
‘Juana starts to sing it.’
b. Empezamos la comida con una ensalada.
start-pres-1pl the meal with a salad
‘We start the meal with a salad.’

The position in which the particles occur in negative complements indicates that their position is above VP. This is so because they precede the negative particle, which itself occurs higher than VP; cf. (47):

(47)
A los dos años los niños empiezan a no querer obedecer a los padres.
at the two years the children start-pres-3pl to not want obey to their parents
‘At the age of two children start to refuse to obey their parents.’

Now, if the Cl Cl versions of Cl Cl verbs requiring infinitival particles involve VP complements, one expects the particles to be absent in these versions. As can be deduced from the examples in (48) this is not the case, however: 34

(48)
a. Juana lo
empieza a cantar t.
Juana it start-pres-3sg to sing
‘Juana starts to sing it.’
b. Juana lo
tendrá que hacer t.
Juana it have-fut-3sg that do
‘Juana has to do it.’

A final indication that Cl Cl complements have more structure than VPs comes from sentences containing Italian interrogative sapere ‘know’. As discussed in Rizzi (1978), this verb marginally admits Cl Cl when its complement contains a fronted wh-word, which under standard assumptions must be in spec, CP: 35

(49)
Su questo punto, non ti
saprei che dire t.
On this point, not you know-cond-1sg what tell
‘On this point, I wouldn't know what to tell you.’

subsection.heading: 3.3.3 Control Cl Cl verbs
subsection.p: If Cl Cl verbs are treated as auxiliaries they must necessarily be assumed not to have a subject of their own. However, a subjectless analysis for control verbs allowing Cl Cl is problematic in light of the fact that, under standard assumptions, these verbs assign a theta-role to the DP in their subject position and exercise selectional restrictions on it, unlike raising verbs. These properties explain, for instance, the grammaticality contrast in (50), where este hombre ‘this man’ can bear the theta-role assigned by querer ‘want’, but este tipo de película ‘this kind of movie’ is incompatible with this role:

(50)
a. Este hombre me
quiere dar escalofríos t.
This man me want-pres-3sg give shivers
‘This man wants to make me shiver.’
b. Este tipo de película me
quiere dar escalofríos t.
this kind of movie me want-pres-3sg give shivers
‘This kind of movie tends to make me shiver.’

The assumption that Cl Cl control verbs assign a theta-role to their subject also explains why, unlike their raising counterparts, these verbs cannot occur with expletive subjects (which are non-overt in the languages under consideration). The Italian examples in (51), from Burzio (1986: 362), are intended to illustrate the raising (51a) vs. control (51b) contrast in Cl Cl constructions: 36

(51)
a. pro ci
dovrebbe essere t
molta gente a la festa.
there CI have-cond-3sg be many people at the party
‘There would have to be many people at the party.’
b. *pro ci
vorrebbe essere t
molta gente a la festa.
there CI want-cond-3sg be many people at the party
‘There would want to be many people at the party.’

Facts like those in (50) and (51) indicate in particular that control verbs in Cl Cl constructions cannot be assumed to have lost the property of necessarily co-occurring with a subject of their own. 37
This is also corroborated by the fact that there is no essential semantic distinction between Cl Cl variants and in situ variants for these verbs.

subsection.heading: 3.4 Summary
subsection.p: Below we summarize the problems for the VP option of the Dual Subcategorization Hypothesis:

li.p: Some (Italian) Cl Cl participles always determine the form of the perfective auxiliary (essere).
(Italian) Cl Cl verbs do not undergo Aux-to-C.
Some (Italian) Cl Cl verbs may undergo passive formation.
Cl Cl complements may contain infinitival particles, which occur higher than VP.
Cl Cl complements may marginally contain a fronted wh-word.
Some Cl Cl verbs assign a theta-role to their subject.

subsection.heading: 4.1 Introduction
subsection.p: Cl Cl verbs are sometimes called ‘restructuring verbs’. The term ‘restructuring’ comes from an extremely influential article by Luigi Rizzi on Cl Cl in Italian (Rizzi 1978). The generalization it covers is that the verb of an infinitival complement can lose its independent status during the derivation, with the result that the phrases it semantically heads (VP, IP, CP) become inoperative (that is they can be considered to be absent). Restructuring would be (optionally) triggered by Cl Cl verbs, but not by other infinitival selecting verbs. The process, which we represent schematically in (52), entails a fusion of the complement clause and the matrix clause into one clausal structure: 38

(52)
Restructuring (optional):
[VP V [IP [VP V]]] → [VP V+V]
[VP V [CP [IP [VP V]]]] → [VP V+V]

subsection.heading: 4.2 The verbal complex
subsection.p: As stated above, Restructuring is brought about because the complement verb loses its independent status. How does this happen? The answer is that the matrix verb and the complement verb come to form one ‘verbal complex’, which as such then functions as the head of the whole clause. Before discussing the status of this complex in the languages we are considering, it is worth noticing that other language groups present more clear-cut evidence for the presence of such a complex in constructions comparable to the Romance Cl Cl ones. Examples are the Dutch and German Verb-Raising constructions (see chapter 75), which arguably involve adjunction of the complement verb to the matrix verb and Verb Incorporation constructions, such as those ocurring in, for instance, the Inuit languages, in which the complement verb is incorporated into the matrix verb. Verb Raising and Verb Incorporation are triggered by roughly the same class of verbs as our Cl Cl verbs, and involve analogous violations of the Clause Mate Condition.

Now, one possible hypothesis about the verbal complex in Romance Cl Cl constructions is that it has essentially the same features as Verb Raising and/or Verb Incorporation complexes. The latter two differ from each other in that verbs triggering Verb Raising are morphologically independent, whereas Incorporation Verbs are affixes, whose morphological requirements are satisfied by the incorporated verb. The morphological independence of Verb Raising verbs manifests itself by the fact that they move out of the verbal complex when further verb movement is required in the matrix domain. Romance Cl Cl verbs are clearly not affixes and, as we discussed in section 1.2.5, (at least in Italian) they can be separated from the complement verb by adverbials when they undergo V-to-I movement. This means that if the Romance verbal complex is to be equated with the verbal complexes of either Dutch/German or Inuit, it patterns with the former. (53) presents an example of the relevant aspects of a Dutch sentence, before (53a) and after Verb Raising (53b): 39

(53)
a. . . . dat Juana [PRO het lied zingen] wil
. . . that Juana
the song sing want-pres-3sg
‘. . . that Juana wants to sing the song’
b. . . . dat Juana [PRO het lied] wil+zingen
(54) contains the analogous pair for Spanish, under the same analysis:

(54)
a. . . . que Juana quiere [PRO cantar la canción]
. . . that Juana want-pres-3sg sing the song
‘. . . that Juana wants (to) sing the song’
b. . . . que Juana quiere+cantar [PRO la canción]

Observe that in the SOV language Dutch the order between the embedded and the matrix verb is inverted, a fact that provides clear evidence for the existence of the creation of the verbal complex. 40 This type of evidence is unavailable in the Romance Cl Cl languages. One might assume that this follows from the SVO nature of these languages and the fact that for some reason the complement verb always surfaces as the right-hand member of the complex (as we have assumed for (54b)). But notice that we know that at least in Italian the matrix verb can undergo V-to-I movement alone, thereby disrupting the putative complex. It might well be the case that this lonesome V-to-I movement is the general picture in Romance Cl Cl languages (recall that in these languages verbs always move to I). If this is so, the (putative) complex will never surface as such and might well have been created by attachment to the left.

Thus, the existence of a complex of the Dutch/German kind is difficult, if not impossible, to provide independent evidence for in Romance. Let us assume, nevertheless, that it is created at some stage. We have to consider, then, what is the right configuration for this to happen. We follow here the current standard assumptions about the formation of head complexes, which is that such complexes are created by adjunction of the lower head to the higher head, as an instance of head movement. A well-known property of head movement is that the target head must govern the maximal projection of the source head, which entails that intervening heads may not be skipped. For IP complements this means that the complement verb first has to move to I – to which it adjoins under standard assumptions – and then adjoins, together with I, to the matrix verb. CP complements require an additional step: V+I has to pass through C. In (55) we exemplify with the derivation for Juana quiere cantar la canción (‘Juana wants to sing the song’). For the sake of concreteness we go on assuming that the adjunction to the matrix verb is to the right, but nothing hinges on this:

(55)
a. Juana quiere [CP C [IP PRO I [VP cantar la canción]]] →
b. Juana quiere+[cantar+I] [CP t [IP PRO t [VP t la canción]]]
The assumption that Cl Cl necessarily involves the creation of a verbal complex by means of head-movement accounts well for a number of properties of the Cl Cl construction:

li.p: In the first place, the complement must be governed by the matrix verb, because otherwise adjunction of the complement verb to the latter is excluded.

Furthermore, any intervening head that blocks V→I(→C)→V movement will prevent formation of the complex and hence Cl Cl. This holds true, for instance, for the lexical C of finite sentences and also for the negative particle, at least under the assumption that in the relevant languages this particle is a head occurring above I (cf. Zanuttini 1991). 41 Thus the non-applicability of Cl Cl out of finite complements and complements with a negative particle follows automatically.

Likewise, the impossibility of having an intervening lexical head – as distinct from a Cl Cl verb – insures the local character of Cl Cl. When such a head is a Cl Cl verb complex, verb formation may be assumed to proceed stepwise.

Another property of Cl Cl complements, discussed in section 1.2.5, was that they show restrictions with respect to fronting of the complement. Such restrictions also seem to follow. Moving the CP/IP prior to complex verb formation will destroy the required government relation between the matrix verb and the complement. After creation of the complex, the embedded verb and the complement are different constituents, so that one doesn't expect them to move together. Notice that cases in which the complement does seem to move (section 1.2.5) might be instances of Remnant VP Movement, applying after Restructuring, movement of the matrix V to I and Cl Cl.

subsection.p: Before going on to the next subsection, in which we will discuss the effects of Restructuring for Cl Cl and its corollaries, we must pay attention to two points that may be problematic for Romance complex verb formation. The first concerns the presence of infinitival particles (cf. (48) above). These particles, which occur between the two verbs, have to be assumed to form part of the verbal complex. The details of this remain to be worked out. The second point concerns the (marginal) possibility of Cl Cl out of complements with wh-phrases preceding the complement verb (cf. (49)): this seems to be unaccountable under the hypothesis that Cl Cl always involves the complex under consideration.

In what follows we’ll go on assuming that the verbal complex is formed by concrete adjunction, ignoring the problems discussed above. It should be mentioned, however, that these problems have not gone unnoticed, and various alternatives to verbal complex formation in Romance have been proposed in order to deal with them. According to Rizzi (1978), in fact, the verbal complex is formed as a consequence of reanalysis of linearly adjacent lexical elements in the terminal string. More specifically, given the string V (C) Subj V, where C is empty/absent and Subj is PRO or trace, the latter are ignored and the two verbs come to form one complex, by rebracketing: [VComplex V (C) Subj V]. Rizzi explicitly allows infinitival particles and wh-elements to form part of the complex, and also adverbials (the fact that the order V–Adv–V was produced by V-movement to I was not known at the time). More recent proposals involve, for instance, reindexing (Zubizarreta 1980) or covert incorporation (Baker 1988a). Roberts (1997b) develops the interesting hypothesis that the effect of adjunction is invisible because the adjoined verb is spelled out in the position of its trace.

subsection.heading: 4.3 Restructuring and (the corollaries of) Cl Cl
subsection.p: Let us now consider how the Restructuring Hypothesis accounts for Cl Cl and its corollaries.

As mentioned earlier, the effect of complex verb formation is that the complement and matrix clause restructure to one simplex clause. The semantic head of this clause is the verbal complex. The matrix subject now acts as the structural subject of this complex, and the same holds true, mutatis mutandis, of the objects and adjuncts of the (original) complement verb. This, obviously, raises questions about the semantic relations in the restructured clause as well as about the status of the original complement subject. We will return to those in section 3.3.2. The structures in (56) illustrate the effect of Restructuring for a Raising (56a) and Control (56b) verb with a transitive complement. In the restructured versions we put the complement subject between brackets, in line with Rizzi's assumption that it is irrelevant for the other structural relations in the clause:

(56)
a. [CP [IP DP [VPV [IP t [VP V DP]]]]] → [CP [IP DP [VPV+V (t) DP]]]
b. [CP [IP DP [VPV [CP [IP PRO[VP V DP]]]]]] → [CP [IP DP [VPV+V (PRO) DP]]]

Let us suppose (as did Rizzi at the time) that the factors that constrain Cl Pl, DP-Movement, and Null Operator Movement, and account for the lack of Cl Cl, Long DP-Movement, and Long Null Operator Movement with standard verbs, are constraints on the application of rules. If this is so, the assumption that the rules under consideration – when targeting a position in the (original) matrix clause – apply after Restructuring leads to the required results: as the rules apply freely within simplex clauses and as the effect of Restructuring is precisely that of producing a simplex clause, the constraints must have been neutralized at that point.

An alternative view, which produces the same result, is that the relevant constraints are conditions on S-structures. In this view, the moment of application of Restructuring is irrelevant. Cl Pl, DP-Movement, and Null Operator Movement can apply in such a way that they target the matrix clause, without Restructuring having yet taken place. The result, of course, will only be grammatical at S-structure if Restructuring does subsequently occur.

Under Restructuring the Italian Avere → Essere Shift can be equated to Auxiliary Choice in simplex clauses, along the lines presented in Burzio (1986). According to Burzio, the choice of avere vs. essere is not directly dependent on the type of the main verb, but on the structural relations within the clause. In particular, essere is required in the ‘ergative’ S-structure configuration in (57), where the subject binds its trace in direct object position, and avere otherwise:
(57) [DPi Aux [VP Part ti]]

Consider now the derivation of (37b), repeated here as (58a), which constitutes the prototypical example of Avere → Essere Shift. From its D-structure in (58b) we derive the structure in (58c), by moving the complement direct object (PRO) to the subject position of the complement. As the structure is one of subject control, the index of the chain PRO–trace is the same as that of the matrix subject. Restructuring now produces the simplex (58d), in which the relation between the subject DP Mario and the trace is structurally identical to the relation between the subject and its trace in (57). Given this, the required auxiliary is essere: 42

(58)
a. Mario è voluto tornare a casa.
Mario be-pres-3sg wanted come back to house
‘Mario has wanted to come back home.’
b. [Mario Aux [VP voluto [CP [IP ec [VP tornare PRO a casa]]]]]
c. [Marioi Aux [VP voluto [CP [IP PROi [VP tornare ti a casa]]]]]
d. [Marioi Aux [VP voluto+tornare (PROi) ti a casa]]
Two questions that remain to be considered here are:

li.p: Can the Restructuring Hypothesis account for the fact that Cl Cl doesn't permit clitic splitting (cf. section 1.2.2)?
Can this hypothesis account for the (lack of) correlation between Cl Cl and its ‘corollaries’, as summarized in section 2.5?

subsection.p: As we will see below, these questions, which are closely related, have as yet not been answered in a satisfactory way.

One possible view on Cl Pl is that it necessarily applies after Restructuring (or that it targets the highest possible position allowed by S-structure constraints). In cases with more than one clitic in the complement, this would automatically involve climbing of all clitics, so that clitic splitting would not occur. It would also explain why there is a correlation between Long DP-Movement and Long Operator Movement (which are dependent on Restructuring) and Cl Cl.

Paradoxically, however, the fact that a ‘Restructuring phenomenon’ such as the Avere → Essere Shift co-occurs with clitics in situ suggests that restructuring does not automatically imply Cl Cl, that is, that Cl Pl in Restructuring constructions has the choice of targeting either the complement verb or the matrix verb. If this is so, there must be independent explanations for the correlations mentioned in the preceding paragraph. We are forced to conclude that further research is required on this point.

subsection.heading: 4.4 Restructuring and the T-model of grammar
subsection.p: The Restructuring Hypothesis accounts for many of the characteristics of Cl Cl constructions. The problems it meets with respect to infinitival particles are presumably not unsolvable, and the same holds true for the (lack of) correlation with other Restructuring phenomena and the prohibition against split clitics. The construction with fronted wh-phrases occurring between the verbs involved seems to remain a problem, but its marginality may indicate that it does not pertain to the core case of Cl Cl and that perhaps there is another explanation for it (in which case, of course, it also would no longer constitute a counter-example to the Dual Subcategorization Hypothesis). There remains, however, a serious conceptual problem, which we’ll now proceed to discuss.

The problem under consideration arose as a consequence of a shift in ideas about the organization of grammar that occurred after Rizzi wrote his article. The current model of that time was the so-called Extended Standard Theory, in which, crucially, D-structure formed the input to semantic interpretation. Within this model, Restructuring affects the syntactic structure, but doesn't have any semantic consequences. Later developments led to the ‘T-model’ of grammar, in which semantics was considered to be dependent on S-structure. It is easy to see that Restructuring, as proposed by Rizzi, is problematic within this model.
Consider once more the Restucturing derivations in (56), repeated here as (59):

(59)
a. [CP [IP DP [VPV [IP t [VP V DP]]]]] → [CP [IP DP [VPV+V (t) DP]]]
b. [CP [IP DP [VPV [CP [IP PRO[VP V DP]]]]]] → [CP [IP DP [VPV+V (PRO) DP]]]

In the T-model the derived structures at the right-hand side form the input to the semantic component. However, we know that Restructuring is optional and that non-restructured clauses have the same interpretation as their restructured counterparts. This entails that semantically the derived structures must be interpreted as identical to their basic structures at the left-hand side. But how can that be achieved? For instance, the IP/CP complement, categorially and semantically required by the matrix verb, has disappeared altogether (observe that this also raises the question as to what happens with the functional heads (I,C) of the complement). Moreover, the structural relations between the two verbs and their arguments are not the ones from which one normally deduces the type of thematic relations they hold. Thus, the DP object isn't contained in the VP uniquely headed by the V of which it is the internal argument and, similarly, the subject DP bearing the external argument of the (original) matrix verb (in the control construction) isn't governed by the VP of which this verb is the sole head. Another point concerns the status of the complement subjects. We have seen that the latter play no active syntactic role in the restructured clause, which might indicate that they are actually absent. But if this is so, how can the presence of the thematic roles they transmit (59a) or bear (59b) be accounted for? If they are present, on the other hand, their interpretation poses problems analogous to that of the other DPs.

We cannot but conclude that, given the T-model (or any model in which interpretation is dependent on the output of transformations), Restructuring, as proposed by Rizzi, too strongly affects the structure of complex clauses.

subsection.heading: 5 Less radical forms of Dual Subcategorization and Restructuring
5.1 Introduction
subsection.p: We know at this point that the VP option of the Dual Subcategorization Hypothesis is empirically problematic and that Restructuring in the sense proposed by Rizzi is too strong in the light of later developments of the theory of grammar. This seems to indicate that the attempts to reduce Cl Cl constructions to one single clause don't lead to the required result. On the other hand, it would be implausible to assume that the intuitions behind this line of research – which was extremely strong from the middle of the 1970s to the beginning of the 1980s – are totally unfounded. What seems to be the case is that the implementation of these intuitions has led to results that involve the absence or elimination of too much structure. An obvious step then is to investigate whether more subtle approaches, which still maintain the hypothesis that Cl Cl and its corollaries follow from the fact that the complement lacks certain clausal properties at the relevant level of representation, fare better. Actually, since the early 1980s, various linguists have developed hypotheses along these lines, thereby often using far more intricate theoretical tools than were available earlier on, but clearly not neglecting the considerable number of insights that were attained before. Below we briefly present some main aspects of these later developments.

subsection.heading: 5.2 Weak variants of the Dual Subcategorization Hypothesis
subsection.p: According to the canonical version of the Dual Subcategorization Hypothesis, Cl Cl verbs select two types of complements: normal CP/IP complements and ‘poorer’ VP complements. The optionality of Cl Cl follows from the fact that only in the latter case do clitics attach to the higher verb. The two hypotheses to be discussed below are also based on the idea that besides normal complements – which don't allow for Cl Cl – Cl Cl verbs may take impoverished (infinitival) complements – which require Cl Cl.

subsection.heading: 5.2.1 Cl Cl complements without theta-roles
subsection.p: The idea that is pursued in Roberts (1997b) is that complements of Cl Cl verbs are always structurally complete, but may be semantically defective. He claims, more specifically, that such verbs can behave ‘auxiliary-like’ in the sense that they may fail to assign a theta-role to their infinitival complement. The lack of this role has as a consequence that syntactic rules don't interpret this complement as a clause. 43 In other words, processes relating positions in the complement to positions in the matrix clause will not violate the Clause Mate Condition. In (60) we present a schematic representation of this approach: (60a) is the normal case for infinitival complements, including the non-Cl Cl variant of Cl Cl verbs, while (60b) is the option that allows for Cl Cl and its corollaries:

Notice that this analysis eliminates all the problems resulting from the lack of clausal structure under the VP option of the Dual Subcategorization Hypothesis (sections 3.3.2, 3.3.3). However, the assumption that Cl Cl verbs may behave ‘auxiliary-like’ seems to be somewhat stipulative, in particular in light of the fact that (non-raising) Cl Cl verbs remain able to theta-mark their own subject, or, in the case of unaccusatives (cf. note 10), object.

subsection.heading: 5.2.2 Cl Cl complements with impoverished I
subsection.p: Another alternative to the canonical Dual Subcategorization Hypothesis is one in which Cl Cl climbing complements optionally lack some structure, but not as much as is assumed under the VP option. This possibility is opened up by certain new insights into the structure of the clause in general.

We have hitherto been assuming that, in addition to V, clauses contain at most two other heads, I and C. The latter are called functional heads. Since the early 1990s there has been a strongly growing insight that I and C are not sufficient to account for the empirical complexity of clauses. As a consequence, I is now assumed to split up in several distinct functional heads (with their concomitant projections). This assumption is known as the Split Infl Hypothesis. We must mention that there is as yet no clear agreement as to the number of these heads, or as to their precise status, This is the reason why in (61), which represents a normal clause, we simply reproduce them as I1, I2 . . . In:
(61) [CP C [IP1 I1 [IP2 I2 . . . [IPn In [VP V]]]]]

It may be the case now that, in addition to a complete CP/IP1 complement, Cl Cl verbs may select an infinitival complement in which some (or only one) of the Ix heads and their projections are absent and that this is precisely what allows for Cl Cl. This idea, to which we’ll briefly return in section 6.3.2, is explored in Martins (2000).

subsection.heading: 5.3 Intermezzo: Cl Cl verbs as functional categories
subsection.p: The introduction of the Split Infl Hypothesis mentioned above has opened the possibility that Cl Cl verbs themselves function as functional heads; that is, that they are lexicalizations of notions (such as aspect and modality) that belong to the functional domain (i.e., the domain above VP in (61) of the clause). This position is defended extensively in Cinque (2000b). It should be mentioned here that Emonds (1999) also classifies Cl Cl verbs as functional categories. In his approach, this term stands for closed classes of categories that lack purely semantic features and behave or may behave distinctly from their lexical counterparts (i.e., from non-Cl Cl verbs in the case under consideration). Both in Cinque's and in Emond's proposal, Cl Cl constructions are simplex clauses and as such pose at least a number of the problems summarized in section 3.4. Especially in Cinque (2000b), some of these are adressed explicitly.

subsection.heading: 5.4 Weak Restructuring
subsection.p: One effect of canonical Restructuring is that it crucially alters the relations between constituents in the clause. Various researchers have claimed that such an alteration can be obtained without the elimination of structure assumed by Rizzi (1978). 44 Most of them do assume some form of complex verb formation. Perhaps the most articulate proposal along these lines is the one formulated in Baker (1988a: 64), under the name of the Government Transparency Corollary. 45 In (62) we reproduce this principle:
A lexical category which has an item incorporated into it governs everything which the incorporated item governed in its original structural position.

Baker's original proposal was formulated for incorporating languages, in which verbal complexes are headed by affixes. However, there is no bar to extending it to verbal complexes in other languages, as Baker himself does for Romance. For this purpose “incorporated (into)” can be interpreted as ‘adjoined (to)’. In order to discuss the effect of the GTC, we’ll consider the example in (63), which was presented above as (55b):

(63)
Juana quiere+ [cantar+I] [CP t [IP PRO t [VP t la canción]]].
Juana want-pres-3sg sing
the song
‘Juana wants to sing the song.’

As the reader may recall, this example represents the hypothesis that the complement verb of Cl Cl verbs adjoins to the matrix verb, after having passed through I and (in control cases) C of the complement. The result is a complex verb. Given the GTC, now, the matrix verb quiere in (63) governs not only the complement CP itself, but also the object of the adjoined verb (cantar), i.e., la canción. The latter government relation thus abstracts from the presence of the intervening CP, IP, and VP nodes. These nodes, however, remain present, as do the PRO subject and the traces of the complement verb.

In (64) we present the main aspects of this analysis, using boldface to indicate the ‘restructured’ government relation between the matrix verb and the embedded object. We also add the matrix VP node, which is the minimal domain in which this relation is established:
(64) . . . [VP V+[V+I] [CP t [IP PRO t [VP t DP]]]]

Normally VP constituents are free to move out of the minimal VP in which they are governed. The assumption is that this is also the case in structures like (64). It follows that if the object of the complement is a clitic, there is no bar to moving it out of the matrix VP (where it adjoins to the verb, which has moved to matrix I). Similarly, there are no obstructions to Long DP-Movement and Long Operator Movement.

One final remark here is that the proposal hinges crucially on the original government relation between the complement verb and the DP. Extension to other clitics requires proof that the latter are likewise governed by this verb in their base position.

subsection.heading: 6 The constraining factor for Cl Cl in non-Cl Cl contexts
6.1 Introduction
subsection.p: Until this point we have been employing the term ‘Clause Mate Condition’ to express the idea that the rules involved in Cl Cl and its corollaries (Cl Pl, DP-movement, Null Operator Movement, and Avere → Essere Shift) must normally apply within a minimal CP or IP. As indicated in section 1.3, this term is merely descriptive. As such, it abstracts away from the specific factors that are responsible for the fact that ‘long’ applications of these rules are only allowed in the case of Cl Cl complements. In the present section we’ll discuss a number of hypotheses as to what the Clause Mate Condition really stands for. As we have been doing all along, we will concentrate primarily on Cl Cl. In this case, that means that our central question will be: what is the factor that constrains Long Cl Pl (Cl Cl) in normal cases and how come this factor is inoperative in Cl Cl contexts? As for the corollaries of Cl Cl, we’ll only consider what the possible answers to this question imply for them.

As discussed in section 1.3, the minimal domain in which the constraint on Cl Cl must be sought is the domain above the VP in the complement of non-Cl Cl raising verbs. The elements that make up this domain are the IP boundary, the I′ projection, the head I, and the DP subject. This means that the constraint must involve at least one of these elements, i.e., that at least one of the situations in (65) holds true for normal Cl Pl (the exclamation mark indicates the factor involved in the constraint):

Below we consider each of these hypotheses in turn. When relevant, we will also examine how the constraint under consideration can be obviated in Cl Cl cases. In doing so, we will no longer take into consideration the standard Dual Subcategorization and Restructuring Hypotheses, which we have rejected as too strong. (Notice, incidentally, that according to these hypotheses all factors in (65) are absent or inoperative; the same holds true for Cinque's and Emonds's approaches, mentioned in section 5.3, which we will also disregard below.) 46

subsection.heading: 6.2 Hypothesis 1: IP, I′
subsection.p: It is not very plausible that IP or I′ functions as a constraining factor, at least not on its own. Raising constructions such as the one in (66a) (with the non-Cl Cl clitic verb parecer ‘seem’) show that I′ and IP don't block DP-movement. Likewise, they don't block wh-movement (cf. (66b)), or V-movement into C. The latter is attested, for instance, in the Italian Aux-to-C construction in (66c):

(66)
a. Juani [I′
parece [IP ti
haber trabajado mucho]]].
Juan seem-pres-3sg have worked a lot
‘Juan seems to have worked a lot.’
b. No sé [CP
a quiéni [IP [I′
contestar primero ti]]].
not know-pres-1sg to whom answer first
‘I don't know whom to answer first.’
c. [CP Essendosii [IP
le mele [I′ ti
mangiate]]]
being+SI the apples eaten
‘The apples having been eaten . . .’

If the IP (alone) or I′ (alone) were to block Cl Cl, the latter process would be very exceptional. Moreover, it would be difficult to explain why blocking of Cl Cl goes together with blocking of Long DP-Movement and Long Null Operator Movement, which are, respectively, DP-movement and movement to the same position as wh-phrases. We therefore reject the hypothesis that either I′ or IP is the sole constraining factor. 47

subsection.heading: 6.3 Hypothesis 2: I
subsection.p: The choice between I and the subject as the constraining factor for Cl Cl depends crucially on the exact details of Cl Pl in simplex clauses. As we’ll see, the standard assumption about this process favors the assumption that this factor is I, but requires the additional assumption that Cl Cl constructions involve some form of complex verb formation. We will discuss this option first.

subsection.heading: 6.3.1 I and Weak Restructuring
subsection.p: The standard assumption about Cl Pl is the one in (67):

(67)
Cl Pl (standard):
Clitics attach directly to the first available (non-participial) verbal host, after V-movement.

Notice that the alternative, in which the clitic attaches to V before V-movement and V+cl undergo V-movement together, runs into problems in Cl Cl contexts: it predicts that the complement V and its clitics will always surface together, i.e., it only permits an in situ analysis. In short, the existence of Cl Cl forces Cl Pl to be postcyclic, at least under the standard assumption that clitics attach directly to the first available host. 48

Given (67), I functions as the ‘constraining factor’ for Cl Cl out of normal infinitivals. This is so because in the languages under consideration infinitival verbs move to I. This is illustrated in (68a), where the fact that V-to-I movement has applied is corroborated by the presence of the adverb inmediatamente ‘immediately’ between the verb and the object. Given (67), Cl Pl will attach the clitic le to V in I. The result is represented in (68b):

(68)
a. Juan promete darle
inmediatamente el libro.
Juan promise-pres-3sg give him immediately the book
‘Juan promises to give him the book immediately.’
b. Juan promete [CP [IP PRO dar+I+le inmediatamente [VP t el libro t]]]
As (68) implies that the ‘first available host’, i.e., V+I, may not be skipped, clitics cannot end up in a position higher than I.

As for Cl Cl contexts, one must assume here that the complement verb is not an ‘available host’. The hypothesis that Cl Cl constructions involve verbal complex formation (sections 4.2, 5.4) in fact predicts this. This is so because, under standard assumptions, the head of such a complex is the matrix verb. As only heads of complex lexical units are visible for outside rules (cf. Williams 1981b), the complement verb becomes ‘invisible’ and hence unavailable as a host for Cl Pl. It follows that Cl Pl must look higher for the first available host, which is the matrix verb.

Let us illustrate the foregoing with the Cl Cl example in (69a). In (69b) we present its D-structure. (69c) is the structure after V-movement (we assume that the matrix verb moves to matrix I) but before Cl Pl:

(69)
a. Juana lo
quiere ver.
Juana it want-pres-3sg see
‘Juana wants to see it.’
b. Juana I [VP quiere [CP [IP PRO I [VP ver lo]]]]
c. Juana quierei+I [VP ti+verj+I [CP tj [IP PRO tj [VP tj lo]]]]

(67) now forces the clitic lo to look for the first available verbal host. Given the fact that ver is a non-head in the complex t+ver+I, it is unavailable. Thus, the clitic attaches to the higher quiere+I.

Under the assumption that verbal complex formation triggers some form of (weak) Restructuring (section 5.4), the violation of the Clause Mate Condition for the corollaries of Cl Cl involves the same considerations as those discussed before in sections 4.3 and 5.4.

subsection.heading: 6.3.2 I and the target of V-movement
subsection.p: An influential alternative to the standard view on Cl Pl, first proposed in Kayne (1989b), makes a crucial distinction between preverbal clitics (proclisis) and postverbal clitics (enclisis):

(70)
Cl Pl (alternative 1):
proclisis: Clitics attach to the first available verbal host.
enclisis: Clitics attach to the first designated inflectional head.

One important extra element of this proposal is that in the case of enclisis the target of verb movement is not the head to which the clitic attaches, but the position to the immediate left of this head.

In Romance Cl Cl languages, where infinitivals require enclisis, infinitival I functions as a designated host for Cl Pl. This entails that clitics move to I and that the verb surfaces to the immediate left of I (it adjoins to I′ in Kayne's proposal). This gives the following analysis for, e.g., (68):
(71) Juan promete [CP [IP PRO dar [I le+I inmediatamente [VP t el libro t]]]]
Under this analysis, infinitival I acts as the constraining factor for Cl Cl out of normal infinitival complements because it is the first designated host for Cl Pl and as such may not be skipped.

Notice that, given the fact that the verb and the clitic form separate constituents in this proposal, it becomes possible that the clitic (+I) moves to a higher position on its own. This is precisely what happens in Cl Cl cases, according to Kayne. In his view, Cl Cl verbs are special in that they allow for the I head of their complement to be extracted. When this head contains one or more clitics, extraction will automatically lead to Cl Cl. In (72) we reproduce the result of this analysis for Juana lo quiere ver (= 69a). We assume, with Kayne, that lo+I moves through C and adjoins to the I of the matrix clause, after movement of the finite matrix verb to this position:
(72) Juana [lo+I]j+[quierei+I] [VP ti [CP tj [IP PRO ver [I′ tj VP]]]]
Though Kayne doesn't discuss this, it is possible that the extraction of the I head leads to some form of restructuring, which in turn may provide an explanation for the corollaries of Cl Cl.

Variants based on Kayne's analysis of Cl Pl in infinitivals involve elimination or absence of the constraining inflectional head in Cl Cl complements. For instance, Bok-Bennema and Kampers-Manhe (1994) argue that I adjoins alone to the matrix verb, before Cl Pl. Another example is Martins (2000), who, as mentioned in section 5.2.2, makes use of the Split Infl Hypothesis. As discussed, she proposes that certain of the ‘atoms’ of I (Ix heads) are absent in Cl Cl cases. These include the one that is the designated target of Cl Pl in normal infinitivals.

subsection.heading: 6.3.3 Summary
subsection.p: The two versions of Cl Pl discussed above are the following:

(73)
Cl Pl (standard):
Clitics attach directly to the first available (non-participial) verbal host, after V-movement.
Cl Pl (alternative 1):
proclisis: Clitics attach to the first available verbal host.
enclisis (the relevant case for infinitivals in Cl Cl languages): Clitics attach to the first designated inflectional head. V-movement is to the immediate left of this head.

Each of these entails that I normally functions as the ‘constraining factor’ on Cl Cl, but in different ways. Obviation of the factor in Cl Cl contexts also proceeds differently. In both cases the obviation might trigger Weak Restructuring, which in turn may provide an explanation for the occurrence of the corollaries of Cl Cl. 49 (74) presents a summary of the differences and similarities of the two approaches:

(74)
Cl Pl (standard):
Constraining factor (CF) Cl Cl: [IP I! [VP V Cl]]
Reason CF: V → I before Cl → V+I
Obviation CF in Cl Cl complements: V +I → (C) → Vmatrix
Obviation CF corollaries: Weak Restructuring (?)
Cl Pl (alternative 1):
Constraining factor (CF) Cl Cl: [IP I! [VP V Cl]
Reason CF: Cl → I
Obviation CF in Cl Cl complements: Cl+I → (C) → Imatrix (for variants see end of section 6.3.2)
Obviation CF corollaries: Weak Restructuring?

subsection.heading: 6.4.1 Introduction
subsection.p: Over the years the idea that the presence of the subject of infinitival complements normally prevents clitics leaving these complements has been extremely pervasive. Indeed, most of the proponents of the standard Dual Subcategorization and Restructuring Hypotheses have followed it. Of interest here, in addition, is one analysis we have not discussed so far, which is the one presented in Burzio (1986), as a version of restructuring (cf. note 44). Burzio boldly extracts the VP of the complement over the subject, thereby placing it outside the domain of the latter and obviating the constraint imposed by it, so that any Cl within this VP is free to move to a higher position. In (75) we present a schematic representation of Burzio's VP-Preposing Rule (notice that at that time Romance IPs were assumed to consist solely of a subject and an IP):
(75) Burzio's VP-Preposing Rule:

The reason for the idea that the presence of the subject blocks Cl Cl is to a great extent historical: at the time these hypotheses were developed, extraction from non-finite clauses was generally be assumed to be constrained by the Specified Subject Condition (SSC) of Chomsky (1973), which prohibited relating positions within a clause to positions outside it over a subject DP. Cl Cl, thus, was seen as unexceptional, that is, as obeying the general constraint on extraction rules.

Within the Government and Binding approach (Chomsky 1981), the SSC was replaced by Binding Condition A, which as far as extractions are concerned is only relevant for extractions of DPs. This aspect of Binding Condition A was later subsumed under Rizzi's (1990b) Relativized Minimality requirement, which prohibits (among other things) A-movement from crossing intervening XPs in A-positions, such as subject DPs.

Given these developments, the idea that Cl Cl with non-Cl Cl verbs is constrained by the presence of the complement's subject only seems to be feasible if Cl Cl involves A-movement. That this may be possible is discussed below.

subsection.heading: 6.4.2 Cl Cl and A-movement
subsection.p: At least for direct object clitics, there is empirical evidence that Cl Pl requires intermediate A-movement (this was first observed in Kayne 1989a). Consider in this respect first the Italian example in (76):

(76)
Gianni li
ha mangiati t. Italian
Gianni them-masc have-pres-3sg eaten-masc-pl
‘Gianni has eaten them.’

Crucial here is the agreement between the clitic and the past participle (see chapter 48). Under the standard assumptions that agreement relations are instances of Specifier–Head agreement, we also have to assume that the participle has a specifier (an A-position) and that before cliticizing the clitic passes through its specifier position. In other words, the clitic first undergoes A-movement, or more precisely DP-movement, and is only subsequently cliticized. Thus, instead of (76) we have in fact (77), with two traces:
(77) Gianni li ha [t mangiati t].

If we now look at cases with Cl Cl of an object and a participle in the matrix clause, we see that they also manifest agreement (78a). This entails that we have to assume that the clitic passes through the specifier of the matrix participle (cf. (78b)), and that at least in this case we have a specific instance of Long DP-Movement, which apparently ignores the presence of the subject of the complement:

(78)
a. Gianni li
ha voluti mangiare.
Gianni them-masc have-pres-3sg wanted-masc-pl eat
‘Gianni has wanted to eat them.’
b. Gianni li ha [t voluti [PRO mangiare t]].

An obvious extension of this analysis entails the assumption the relevant specifier position doesn't only occur with agreeing participles, but that all direct object clitics pass through it. Cliticization of such clitics can then be considered to be cliticization from this specifier onto V in I, with as a consequence that Cl Cl of direct object clitics always involves Long DP-Movement.

Notice that in order to extend this analysis to other clitics, it has to be assumed Cl Pl always entails intermediate A-movement to a specifier position; that is, that Cl Pl should be formulated as follows: 50

(79)
Cl Pl (alternative 2):51
step 1: Clitics move to a designated specifier position. (XP-movement)
step 2: Clitics attach to the first available verbal host. (proper Cl Pl)
Given (79) all Cl Cl entails ‘long A-movement’, or, as we will call it, Long XP-Movement.

subsection.heading: 6.4.3 Circumventing the complement's subject
subsection.p: Suppose that Cl Cl indeed involves Long XP-Movement. As discussed in section 6.3.1, this type of movement is normally excluded because it crosses the clausal subject and as such gives rise to a violation of Relativized Minimality. Then we need an account of why this violation doesn't occur in Cl Cl constructions. There are two possibilities: either the subject of Cl Cl complements doesn't count for Relativized Minimality, or there is some way in which XP-movement can circumvent the presence of the subject in such complements. We will consider each of these in turn.

First, it is possible that Relativized Minimality is not exceptionless. In fact, it cannot be so under the assumption that Cl Pl involves intermediate XP-movement. Consider, in this respect, the example in (80a). Here the movement of the indirect object clitic le to the intermediate XP must have crossed the direct object DP (cf. (80b)). As the latter occurs in an A-position, a strict application of Relativized Minimality predicts that the sentence will be ungrammatical, contrary to fact:

(80)
a. Juana le
da el libro.
Juana him give-pres-3sg the book
