‘Juana gives him the book.’
Juana le t [VP da el libro t].

On the basis of similar considerations, Roberts (1997b) claims that Relativized Minimality doesn't hold for A-movement (= XP-movement) in simplex clauses. This means that he in fact reduces Relativized Minimality to the Clause Mate Condition (for A-movement). If we assume that this is correct, any of the analyses of Cl Cl that allow for the apparent violation of the Clause Mate Condition will account for the fact that intermediate XP-movement of clitics can cross the DP-subject of these complements. One such analysis is that in which the complement is semantically defective, under the version proposed by Roberts himself (section 5.2.1). Another one is Baker's version of Weak Restructuring discussed in section 5.4.

The alternative way to circumvent the role of the subject in Cl Cl complements has already been mentioned in section 6.4.1. We refer to Burzio's VP-Preposing Rule. Notice, however, that given later insights, it cannot be solely the VP that preposes. This is so because the complement's V undergoes V-movement to I (section 3.3.2), and preposing the VP before this movement takes place would make it impossible for this rule to apply. Preposing it after V-movement, on the other hand, makes wrong predictions with respect to word order: DP complements of the verb would surface to its left, contrary to fact; cf. (81):

(81)
a. *Juana te
quiere el libro mostrar.
Juana you want-pres-3sg the book (to) show
b. Juana te quiere ti [VP tj el libro ti]k [PRO mostrarj+I tk].

An adaptation of Burzio's rule to a more actual framework is presented in Haverkort (1993), who makes use of the Split Infl Hypothesis (section 5.2.2) and places the first IPx which follows the subject out of the domain of the latter. For Haverkort, who claims that all infinitivals have a complementizer, the target position of IPx is the specifier of C. In (82) we present the essential aspects of Haverkort's rule, before (82a) and after (82b) preposing of the post-subject constituent (IP2), to the specifier position of I1. (We abstract from the V-movement within IP2.) 52

(82)
a. . . . [CP C [IP1 subject I1 [IP2 I2 [VP V XP]]]]
b. . . . [CP [IP2 I2 [VP V XP]]i C [IP1 subject I1 ti]]

The effect of preposing IP2 is in essence the same as that of Burzio's VP preposing. In (82a) the presence of the subject blocks XP-movement out of the complement. In (82b) this is no longer the case and Long XP-Movement may freely apply. Within this analysis, Cl Cl verbs are special in that they allow for preposing of the constituent which follows the subject (IP2) to the first position of their complement. It should be observed that the analysis can of course only be valid if the preposing rule itself is not sensitive to the presence of the subject.

One remaining question is whether these types of accounts may also hold for the corolloraries of Cl Cl. For Long DP-Movement this goes without saying, simply because it is an instance of Long XP-Movement. As for Long Null Operator Movement and Avere → Essere Shift, we must consider to what extent it is plausible that they are normally prohibited because of the fact that the presence of the subject of the complement induces a Relativized Minimality Violation. As for Long Null Operator Movement, it is possible that this rule, which always consists of movement of an object DP, involves the same intermediate XP-movement we are assuming for Cl Pl. If this is so, it will indeed be subject to the same constraint. As for the Avere → Essere Shift, recall that it requires the subject of the matrix clause to be related to the trace of PRO in the object position of the complement clause (section 4.3). Though this remains to be worked out, it isn't impossible that it is indeed Relativized Minimality that normally prevents this relation from being established over the (PRO) subject of the complement.

subsection.heading: 6.4.4 Summary
subsection.p: In (83) we repeat the version of Cl Cl presented in (79):

(83)
Cl Pl (alternative 2):
step 1: Clitics move a designated specifier position. (XP-movement)
step 2: Clitics attach to the first available verbal host. (proper Cl Pl)

This version entails that the subject functions as the ‘constraining factor’ for Cl Cl in normal cases. There are at least three kinds of possible explanation for the fact that this factor is obviated (or is inoperative) in Cl Cl complements. It is possible that these account at the same time for the occurrence of the corollaries of Cl Cl. Below we summarize our findings:

(84)
Cl Pl (alternative 2):
Constraining factor (CF) Cl Cl: [IP DP! [VP V Cl]]
Reason CF: Relativized Minimality
Obviation CF in Cl Cl complements: a. defectiveness IP (CP)
b. Weak Restructuring
c. IxP preposing
Obviation CF corollaries: same as for Cl Cl (??)

subsection.heading: 6.5 Conclusion
subsection.p: The central question we have been considering in this section is: what is the factor that constrains Long Cl Pl (Cl Cl) in normal cases and how come this factor is inoperative in Cl Cl contexts? As possible factors we have considered the complement's IP, I′, I, and the complement's subject. We have seen that the first two are not plausible candidates (section 6.2). The choice between the remaining two is to be strictly linked to the question of what is the exact nature of Cl Pl. Under the hypothesis that the factor is I, this question also plays a crucial role in the determination of what causes its inoperativeness in Cl Cl contexts. Answers to this latter question, however, provide no direct explanation for the corollaries of Cl Cl. Under the hypothesis that the factor is the subject, on the other hand, its inoperativeness (possibly) does entail such an explanation. The explanation of inoperativeness itself, however, is independent from the nature of Cl Pl and must be sought in a different direction. Albeit in updated versions, the hypotheses formulated in the earlier years of Generative Grammar remain relevant for this search. They also continue to play a role under the hypothesis that the factor is I, in particular in the investigation of the reason of the existence of the corollaries of Cl Cl.

It should be mentioned here that Zubizarreta (1980: 150) states that Cl Cl out of Right Node Raised complements is acceptable in Spanish. She observes that Right Node Raising might be a discourse rule and as such not relevant to syntax.

15 Cl Cl approaches based on the idea that clitics – or feature bundles spelled out as clitics – are base-generated in clitic positions are, e.g., Strozer (1976), LaPolla (1988), and, more recently, Miller and Sag (1997) and Emonds (1999). One specific view on the base generation of clitics is the one presented in Sportiche (1996b): see note 51.

16 Notice that this implies that when we speak of clitics in situ – as opposed to climbed clitics – we do not refer to their base position, but to the position they move to within their own (minimal) clause.

17 It should be mentioned here that there are in fact more cases in which the verbal host is not responsible for the semantic role expressed by the clitic: as discussed extensively in Emonds (1999), Romance clitics can also be semantically dependent on adjectival predicates, quantifiers or nouns, as in (i–iii), respectively:

subsection.p:
(i)
Eso me
resulta difícil.
this me result-pres-3sg difficult
‘This is difficult for me.’

(ii)
Ne
arrivano molti. Italian
of-them arrive-past-3pl many
‘Many of them arrived.’

(iii)
Ne
conosco l’autore. Italian
of-it know-pres-1sg the author
‘I know the author of that.’
The point made below in the text, which is that Clitic Placement is normally restricted to clauses (CP/IP), also holds in these cases.

p.span: 18 For aspectual auxiliaries we take over the analysis presented in Zagona (1988b).
19 Though some authors assume that Cl Cl takes place after intraclausal Cl Pl. Examples are Kayne (1989b) and Rooryck (1994a). See also section 6.3.2.
20 The term “Clause Mate Condition” is originally due to Ross (1986).
21 For details see Cinque (1988). See also chapter 42.
22 Raising Cl Cl verbs allow similar reflexive passives, as, e.g., in (i):

subsection.p:
(i)
Los plátanos se
suelen comer con las manos.
The bananas SE tend-pres-3pl eat with the hands
‘Bananas are usually eaten with your hands.’
In this case, however, we have to do with passivization in the complement clause and subsequent raising of the complement subject DP, as well as Cl Cl of se.

p.span: 23 However, Rooryck (1994a) mentions that with the Italian verbs cercare di ‘try to’ and provare a ‘try to’, which allow Cl Cl for some speakers, Long DP-Movement is excluded. Moreover, there are Spanish speakers who exclude it with querer ‘want’. For a possible explanation of this latter fact see Bok-Bennema and Kampers-Manhe (1994).

24 Null Operator Movement in Romance is much more restricted than, e.g., in English. In fact it only involves direct objects. Kayne (1989b) suggests that the Romance null operator undergoes Cl Pl (prior to movement to C). This might be interpreted as meaning that this operator is a covert accusative [+wh] clitic.

25 According to Zubizarretta (1980), in certain Spanish and Italian dialects sentences such as the one in (i), with clitics in situ, are grammatical. If this is so, the correlation between Cl Cl and Long Null Operator Movement is not absolute for all speakers:

subsection.p:
(i)
Esta mesa será difícil de poder venderte.
this table be-fut-3sg hard to can sell+you
‘This table will be hard to be able to sell you.’

p.span: 26 As raising verbs are essere verbs, the relevant Cl Cl verbs here are the control verbs, with the exception of andare and venire, which – in addition to being control verbs – are unaccusative and hence require essere.
27 For further details, see Burzio (1986: 364ff.).

28 Burzio (1986: 381) mentions one clear exception: Cl Cl verbs which require the infinitival particle di, such as finire di ‘finish to’, systematically exclude the Avere → Essere Shift. Boysen (1977) states that the shift for sapere (a Cl Cl verb) was not found in a large corpus of written Italian prose. Cf. also Kayne (1989b: 253).

29 Another Italian corollary of Cl Cl, presented in Rizzi (1978), is Long Dative ‘Loro’ Placement. Apart from the discussion in Rizzi (1978), it is usually not considered in studies on Cl Cl, due to the fact that – as Rizzi puts it – dative loro belongs to “rather stiff style . . . on which many speakers of Italian do not have intuitions at all” (Rizzi 1978: fn. 29).
30 This is disputed by Kayne (1989b) and by Rooryck (1994a), on the basis of facts such as those mentioned in notes 23, 25, and 28.

31 The claim that the Cl Cl variant of Cl Cl verbs selects a VP complement is defended in Strozer (1976), Napoli (1981), Fresina (1982), Picallo (1985, 1990), Di Sciullo and Williams (1987), Rochette (1988), and Rosen (1990), among others.
32 Rizzi (1978) was the first to observe the parallelism between Aux–Adv–V sequences and Cl Cl verb–Adv–V sequences.
33 For details on these particles see Rizzi (1982a: chapter 3), Kayne (1984a: chapter 5), Haverkort (1993) and the references cited there.

34 The Italian examples in (i), from Fresina (1982), illustrate the order infinitival particle–negative particle for this language. The examples in (ii) are added to illustrate the Cl Cl nature of the verbs (+particles) involved:

subsection.p:
(i)
a. Sono riuscito a non leggerlo, quel romanzo pornografico.
be-pres-3pl succeeded to not read+it, that novel pornographic
‘They succeeded in not reading it, that pornographic novel.’
b. La verità, Gianni stava per non dirla, allorché . . .
the truth, Gianni be-past-3sg for not to tell it, then . . .
‘The truth, Gianni was in favor of not telling it, then . . .’

(ii)
a. Le
sono riuscito a parlare t.
him be-pres-3pl succeeded to speak
‘They succeeded in speaking to him.’
b. La verità, Gianni la
stava per tacere t, allorché . . .
the truth, Gianni it be-past-3sg for conceal, then . . .
‘The truth, Gianni was in favor of concealing it, then . . .’

p.span: 35 As discussed in Rooryck (1994a), similar examples with wh-words other than che are excluded by Italian informants (though they marginally allow these when the climbed clitic refers to a left-dislocated phrase). According to Rooryck the relevant distinction between che and other wh-words, such as a chi ‘to whom’ or come ‘how’, is that the former is clitical in nature. It should be mentioned here also that according to LaPolla (1988) examples analogous to (49) in the text are perfect in Mexican Spanish. LaPolla only considers cases with qué (=che).
36 For arguments that ci undergoes Cl Cl and doesn't itself function as the expletive, but is linked to it, see Burzio (1986: 126ff.).

37 As discussed in Burzio (1986: 389, fn. 36), the grammaticality of (i) is surprising, in particular when compared to (51b) in the text. Molti must be assumed to occupy the embedded object position, because ne can only originate from within objects. Nevertheless molti-ne ‘many of them’ is interpreted as also bearing the subject role assigned by vorrebbero. For possible solutions see the aforementioned footnote in Burzio (1986) as well as Zubizarreta (1982a) and Cinque (2004):

subsection.p:
(i)
Ne
vorrebbero venire molti t.
of+them want-cond-3pl come many
‘Many of them would want to come.’

p.span: 38 Restructuring is also known as ‘pruning’ or ‘clause union’. These terms are due to, respectively, Ross (1986) and Aissen and Perlmutter (1976).
39 Dutch main clauses require V-movement to second position. To abstract from this movement we follow the standard convention by presenting these type of examples in the form of a subordinate clause.
40 The SOV character of Dutch is not undisputed. Zwart (1993) was the first to propose that Dutch is in fact an SVO language.

41 While non sapere (Italian) marginally permits Cl Cl over che in the specifier of C (49), Cl Cl over the interrogative complementizer se is excluded. Cf. Kayne (1989b), Rooryck (1994a). This of course is also explained here.

42 This analysis correctly excludes Essere → Avere Shift with andare and venire. As discussed in note 10, the subject of these verbs originates as an object DP in the matrix clause. Restructuring will not affect the trace of this DP. As for the exclusion of this shift in the case of raising verbs, it must be assumed that the trace of the raised subject remains visible for auxiliary selection. See Burzio (1986: chapter 5) for further details.
43 Roberts doesn't use the notion ‘clause’. Instead he makes use of the concept of ‘Extended Projection’, introduced by Grimshaw (1991).

44 Among these are Manzini (1983b) and Goodall (1987b), who claim that both the simplex and the complex structure are present at the same time (Coanalysis). Another example is Zubizarreta (1980), who argues for ‘Thematic Restructuring’; that is, Restructuring at the level of LF. Burzio (1986) presents a special form of Restructuring, in which the VP of the complement is attached under the matrix VP, by means of a rule of VP preposing. We will return to this rule in section 6.4.3.

45 A precursor of the Government Transparency Corollary is the Head Condition, introduced by Zwarts (1975) to account for the transparency of Dutch Verb-Raising complements. Bok-Bennema (1981) applies this condition to Spanish Cl Cl complements.

46 In order to concentrate on the main points, we won't evaluate the specific analyses presented below (in sections 6.3, 6.4) with respect to all characteristics of Cl Cl listed in section 1.2.6. We leave such an evaluation to the reader.

47 There are at least two analyses that claim that IP normally functions as a barrier to Cl Cl. However, these analyses assume that the IP under consideration is the complement of an empty C. The most radical of them is Haverkort (1993), in which all infinitival complements (including raising ones) are CPs. In Haverkort's analysis the barrierhood of IP may be obviated by movement of the Ix projection (cf. section 5.2.2) – which includes the clitic and the verb, but not the subject – into the specifier of C. The central characteristic of Cl Cl verbs is that the C of their complements allows this movement. Ouhalla (1989) claims that Cl Cl is made possible by V-movement to C, which obviates the barrierhood of IP. He only considers control complements. It should be mentioned, in addition, that Kayne (1989b) proposes that Cl Cl has to proceed through C if the latter is present. Here again the reason is obviation of the barrierhood of IP.

48 The postcyclicity of Cl Pl is extensively defended in Kayne (1975). Notice, however, that it is incompatible with the idea, mentioned briefly in section 4.2, that cases such as (17b), repeated here as (i), involve remnant VP-movement: to account for the position of the clitic lo, the latter has to be attached to the verb potevo in I before movement of the remnant:

subsection.p:
(i)
[Leggere a tutti] non lo
potevo.
read to all not it can-past-1sg
‘Read it to everybody, I couldn't.’
Alternatives that don't require postcyclic Cl Pl will be discussed in sections 6.3.2 and 6.4.2.

p.span: 49 In fact, Kayne disputes the fact that what we are calling corollaries do have this status: see note 30. Bok-Bennema and Kampers-Manhe (1994) (see below in the text), on the other hand, claim that the corollaries do indeed follow from Weak Restructuring. They argue that this process also applies in French.
50 This is compatible with the idea defended in Koopman and Szabolcsi (2000) that all XP constituents originated in the VP must move to higher Checking Positions.

51 One interesting alternative dispenses with Cl Pl altogether and equates Cl Cl with Long XP-Movement. This is proposed in Sportiche (1996b) and followed up in Roberts (1997b). Under this view, clitics are base-generated in their surface position, as heads with an empty specifier position (Voice heads). The thematic or adjunct position to which the clitic is related contains an empty XP, which must move to the specifier position of the clitic, which in Cl Cl cases is of course a matrix clause position.
52 For more specific details of Haverkort's analysis, see note 47.

subsection.heading: Appendix 1 Italian examples
subsection.p: Standard example of in situ–Cl Cl alternation:

(1)
a. Mario vuole leggerlo.
Mario want-pres-3sg read+it
‘Mario wants (to) read it.’
b. Mario lo vuole leggere.
Cl Cl with raising verb:

(2)
a. Giovanni dovrebbe prenderlo.
Giovanni must-cond-3sg fetch+it
‘Giovanni would-have to fetch it.’
b. Giovanni lo dovrebbe prendere.
Ungrammaticality Cl Cl with regular subject control verb:

(3)
a. Mario odia leggerlo.
Mario hate-pres-3sg read+it
‘Mario hates to read it.’
b. *Mario lo odia leggere.
Ungrammaticality Cl Cl with regular subject-raising verb:

(4)
a. Angela pareva averlo
accompagnato a casa.
Angela seem-past-3sg have+him taken to house
‘Angela seemed to have taken him home.’
b. *Angela lo pareva avere accompagnato a casa.
((4b) is marginally accepted by some speakers.)
Impossibility of ‘clitic splitting’:

(5)
a. Gianni vi
li
vuole mostrare.
Gianni you-pl them want-pres-3sg show
‘Gianni wants to show them to you.’
b. *Gianni vi vuole mostrarli.
c. *Gianni li vuole mostrarvi.
Cl Cl over sequence of Cl Cl verbs:

(6)
a. Maria vuole andare a prenderli
lei stessa.
Maria want-pres-3sg go to fetch+them her self
‘Maria wants go to fetch them herself.’
b. Maria li vuole andare a prendere lei stessa.
Impossibility of Cl Cl out of finite complement:

(7)
a. Gianni vuole che Maria li
veda.
Gianni want-pres-3sg that Maria them see-subj-pres-3sg
‘Gianni wants for Maria to see them.’
b. *Gianni li vuole che Maria veda.
Ungrammaticality of Cl Cl out of complement with negative particle:

(8)
a. A Mario, potete non parlargli, se preferite.
To Mario, can-pres-2pl not speak+him-dat if prefer-pres2pl
‘To Mario you (pl) don't have to speak, if you prefer to.’
b. *A Mario, gli potete non parlare, se preferite.
(The example above is from Fresina 1982.)

subsection.heading: Appendix 2 Portuguese examples
subsection.p: The examples in this appendix are from Martins (2000), and concern European Portuguese (EP). Notice that in EP clitics are always enclitic on infinitivals and normally enclitic on finite verbs.
Cl Cl with subject control verb:

(1)
a. Quero fazê-lo.
want-pres-1sg do-it
‘I want to do it.’
b. Quero-o fazer.
Cl Cl with subject raising verb:

(2)
O polícia pode-me
multar por excesso de velocidade.
the cop can-pres-3sg-me fine for excess of velocity
‘The cop can fine me for breaking the speed limit.’
(Martins classifies this case as subject control.)
Ungrammaticality Cl Cl with regular subject control verb:

(3)
a. O Pedro crê tê-los
convencido.
the Peter believe-pres-3sg have-them convinced
‘Peter believes to have convinced them.’
b. *O Pedro crê-os ter convencido.
Ungrammaticality Cl Cl with regular subject raising verb:

(4)
*Ele parece-o
odiar.
He seem-pres-3sg-him hate
‘He seems to hate him.’

subsection.heading: Appendix 3 List of Spanish Cl Cl verbs
subsection.p: This appendix contains an overview of the Cl Cl verbs in Spanish. It should be borne in mind, however, that there is considerable variation and hesitancy among speakers as to which verbs belong to this class.
The verbs presented here are basically movement verbs. When they occur with non-finite complements their meaning becomes aspectual, though their basic meaning usually still transpires.

The class of indirect object control verbs is exceptional in that it permits Cl Cl, but only for clitics that refer to non-humans. The list – taken from Luján (1980) – is not exhaustive. Cl Cl with indirect object control verbs is not discussed in the text. We refer the reader to Luján (1980) and Bok-Bennema (1981) for further details and references.
The following verbs are sometimes mentioned as Cl Cl verbs. According to Zubizaretta (1982a) they only classify as such “by analogy.” Observe that they are all subject control verbs.
We add a list containing some of the verbs that take infinitival complements, but normally reject Cl Cl.

subsection.heading: Appendix 4 List of Italian Cl Cl verbs
subsection.p: This appendix contains an overview of the core class of Cl Cl verbs in Italian. It should be borne in mind, however, that even for this core class there are speakers who do not accept Cl Cl with all of them (cf. Rizzi 1982a: 41, fn. 6). For more extensive sets of verbs that (sometimes) allow Cl Cl, see Napoli (1981) and Fresina (1982)
Here we present a small set of examples of verbs that take infinitival complements, but generally reject Cl Cl.
